soc.message

Class SOCPutPiece

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCPutPiece
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, SOCMessageForGame

    public class SOCPutPiece
extends SOCMessage
implements SOCMessageForGame
    Client player is asking to place, or server is announcing placement of, a piece on the board. Also used when joining a new game or a game in progress, to send the game state so far.

    If message is from server for a SOCPlayingPiece.ROAD or SOCPlayingPiece.SHIP: After updating game data with the new piece, client should call SOCGame.getPlayerWithLongestRoad() and update displays if needed.

    If message is from server for a SOCPlayingPiece.CITY while client is joining a game, must precede by sending that client a SOCPutPiece message with the SOCPlayingPiece.SETTLEMENT at the same coordinate which was upgraded to that city.

    If this is a placement request from a client player: If successful, server announces SOCPutPiece to the game along with the new SOCGameState. Otherwise server responds with an explanatory SOCGameServerText and, if the gamestate allowed placement but resources or requested coordinates disallowed it, the current SOCGameState and then a SOCCancelBuildRequest.
    If PutPiece leads to the Longest Route player changing, server v2.4.00 and newer announces that between the SOCPlayerElements and SOCGameState: SOCGameElements(LONGEST_ROAD_PLAYER).

    Some game scenarios use villages which aren't owned by any player; their getPlayerNumber() is -1 in this message.

    See also SOCMovePiece and SOCDebugFreePlace. Messages similar but opposite to this one are SOCCancelBuildRequest and the very-limited SOCRemovePiece.

    Some scenarios like SC_PIRI include some pieces as part of the initial board layout while the game is starting. These will all be sent to the clients while game state is < START1A and before sending them SOCStartGame. Scenario SC_CLVI sends its neutral villages before START1A but as part "CV" of the board layout message, not as SOCPutPieces.

    In v2.0.00 and newer: On their own turn, player clients can optionally request PutPiece in gamestate PLAY1 or SPECIAL_BUILDING which implies a SOCBuildRequest for that piece type, without needing to first send that SOCBuildRequest and wait for a gamestate response. If request is allowed, the server announces SOCPlayerElement messages for the resources spent, and then its usual response to a successful SOCPutPiece. Otherwise the rejection response is sent as described above, and after rejection the gamestate may be a placement state such as PLACING_ROAD.

    Author:
    Robert S Thomas
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • SOCPutPiece

        public SOCPutPiece(java.lang.String na,
                   int pn,
                   int pt,
                   int co)
            throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        create a PutPiece message
        Parameters:
        na - name of the game
        pt - type of playing piece, such as SOCPlayingPiece.CITY; must be >= 0
        pn - player number, or -1 for non-player-owned SOCPlayingPiece.VILLAGE. Sent from server, ignored if sent from client.
        co - coordinates; must be >= 0
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if pt < 0 or co < 0

    • Method Detail

      • getGame

        public java.lang.String getGame()
        Description copied from interface: SOCMessageForGame
        Name of game this message is for, if any. Must not be null in a message sent to the server: If message is not about per-game structures or code, use SOCMessage.GAME_NONE.

        At the server, the message treater dispatches incoming SOCMessageForGames based on their getGame():

        • null: Message is ignored
        • SOCMessage.GAME_NONE: Message is handled by SOCServer itself or SOCServerMessageHandler
        • Any other game name: Looks for a game with that name, to dispatch to the GameHandler for that game's type. If no game with that name is found, the message is ignored.
        Specified by:
        getGame in interface SOCMessageForGame
        Returns:
        the name of the game

      • stripAttribNames

        public static java.lang.String stripAttribNames(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a comma-delimited list for SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String). Converts piece coordinate to decimal from hexadecimal format.
        Parameters:
        messageStrParams - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters without attribute names, or null if params are malformed
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Description copied from class: SOCMessage
        Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

        Within this representation, message parameters should be in same order used by SOCMessage.toCmd() and parseDataStr(..). Should be parseable by SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String) which calls SOCMessage.stripAttribNames(String), which your class can override if needed.

        Specified by:
        toString in class SOCMessage
        Returns:
        a human readable form of the message
        See Also:
        SOCMessage.toCmd()
